lexUnit.name: embarrass.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: cause to feel awkward, self-conscious, or ashamed.

sentence.text: With the Pakistan ball-tampering row at its height , Gower has embarrassed Lord 's by claiming the 1990 India tourists scuffed the ball at The Oval as they pressed for victory .
Moments which we would like to savour disappear in a flash and moments which embarrass us seem interminable .
` The senator obviously just wants us to drown his children so they ca n't embarrass him when the time comes to run for President , " she told me next morning .
It embarrassed her to remember the way Maurin had attracted her but she must not let that embarrassment colour the way she acted now .
It embarrassed him to receive her in his dressing-gown .
The sum changed hands , but underneath the table because it embarrassed him to receive money in public .
It used to embarrass Inder Lal to find me waiting for him .
It embarrasses me to mention it . "
And the two press lords , and some others , certainly wished to embarrass Baldwin .
It would have embarrassed him , even sickened him .
It is a war which has begun to embarrass the interveners .
` I hate Maud , and those lyrics embarrass me . "
But the Government has been severely embarrassed by the burgeoning cost of the programme .
The Free Church Executive was embarrassed by the action and refused permission even though specifically ` Nonconformist " principles had been expunged by the Board .
It seemed to me that she was embarrassed by my family bereavement and felt it was not necessary to be part of it .
She peered appraisingly at herself in the mirror , pulling faces as if she were alone , and I was embarrassed by her candour .
Marlon had been embarrassed by his mum coming to pick him up from the school disco .
The move came after Lutzenberger embarrassed the government by publicly accusing Ibama , the federal agency responsible for protecting the Amazon forest , of corruption and misuse of foreign funds .
Her aunt 's antics embarrassed her and she could feel herself blushing .
She hoped that Constance would not embarrass her by telling Mick that she wished to be a kennel-maid : she 'd changed her mind anyway .
Would release embarrass him or cut him off from that obscure membership of the masculine club ?
She had not the heart to embarrass him by refusing a request so diffidently expressed .
Option two -- investing the trust fund in real assets instead of government paper -- also assumes that honest book-keeping will embarrass politicians into spending less .
A nine-year-old boy and his sister , 11 , who live with their grandparents in Reading , Berks are trying to stop their mother embarrassing them by turning up drunk at the school gates .
His genuine desire to make up may be interpreted as an attempt to embarrass or be-little .
His importunities at times embarrassed or irritated Wilberforce , Stephen and Macaulay who all also doubted his judgement on some issues .
